title: Which Norwegian singers are well-known worldwide? - Quora

response.answer_text: I wouldn’t know, except for Morten Harket - Wikipedia as A-ha - Wikipedia is by far most famous Norwegian band. And the Ylvis - Wikipedia brothers are famous.* Maybe I’m getting old and the younger generation isn’t aware of A-ha, and me not knowing about new stuff. I tried to look up (see below) and wasn’t familiar with any of the names. There’s also Eiríkur Hauksson - Wikipedia, and we Icelanders still want to claim him as one of our most famous singers, while he’s now lived more than half his live in Norway, and has also competed in Eurovision for them in addition to many times for Iceland: is an Icelandic heavy metal vocalist [..] In 1988 Eiríkur moved to Østfold in Norway to become the vocalist of the power metal group Artch. As their vocalist he's known as Eric Hawk. [..] Artch's bassist, Bernt Jansen, is also known as Flash, Wig Wam's bassist. Through this connection Eiríkur has performed backing vocals for Wig Wam. [..] In 1999 Eiríkur sang clean vocals on the album Soulburner by Swedish melodic death metal band Gardenian as a guest. Since 2005, Eiríkur tours Europe as the vocalist of Ken Hensley's live band called Live Fire. [..] In 2007 Eiríkur performed the song "Ég les í lófa þínum" written by Sveinn Rúnar Sigurðsson and Kristján Hreinsson at the Icelandic nationals. The song won the finals with approximately 60% following by televote. Eiríkur represented Iceland in the Eurovision Song Contest in Helsinki in 2007 with the song,[6] although it was performed in English, under the new title "Valentine Lost." Eiríkur is still a great singer (I went to his great 60-year-old birthday/concert).  I was only familiar with A-ha on this list: 9 Musicians from Norway You Need to Know Aurora Some have compared her to Björk, others to Florence Welch. [..] Todd Terje Norway’s space disco is a genre that started 20 years ago with a group of teenagers in the arctic Tromsø, and is still going strong, even beyond the country’s borders.  Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest - Wikipedia Norway has the two dubious distinctions of having finished last in more Eurovision finals than any other country and for having the most "nul points", finishing last 11 times and failing to score a point four times. There are some notable Norwegian Eurowision songs, and we Icelanders understand the Norwegian ones, more or less, while most are in English, including Wig Wam’s and most recent one (now we know what Joik - Wikipedia is, however). Some good singers and song (and the video): Mørland & Debrah Scarlett with "A Monster Like Me" and few others from Eurovision.  Early Norwegian black metal scene - Wikipedia is interesting (I understand, not listed to myself). The 10 best True Norwegian Black Metal bands, as chosen by Mork From that list, I was familiar with that band, only because of the name, seen it on a poster in a venue in Iceland: Dimmu Borgir - Wikipedia The name is derived from Dimmuborgir, a volcanic formation in Iceland, the name of which means "dark cities" or "dark castles/fortresses" in Icelandic, Faroese and Old Norse.  * Ylvis - Wikipedia brothers/comedic duo have a lot of good very funny songs, not only The Fox (What Does the Fox Say?) - Wikipedia. Also e.g. "Stonehenge" and "The Cabin".

As a Brit, I have quite a lot of great Norwegian talent in my Spotify favourites list: AURORAKari BremnesSissel KirkjebøOdd NordstogaKalandraDarling WestHighasakiteSandra LyngRotlausCarina DahlSigrid MoldestadIngebørg BratlandSol Heilo (of Katzenjammer fame)Ine HoemMaria MenaAlan WalkerKatastrofePlumboEYESI have eclectic taste would be an understatement. Of these, I expect AURORA and Highasakite are internationally well known. Honestly, the Norwegian (and broader Nordic) music scene is pretty epic and I love it. It’s certainly very useful for someone trying to tune their ears to the language.

The most famous singer is probably Sissel Kyrkjebø. She was the one who was supposed to sing “My heart will go on” for Titanic, until she was replaced by Celine Dion in the last minute, as they wanted a more famous name given the huge budget deficit of the movie. In Hi-Fi circles, the name Kari Bremnes is quite well known internationally, because of her extreme focus on sound quality in her productions. Of course, we’ve also had some international megahits, e.g. “Aha” with “Take on me”, and “Katzenjammer” who had huge international success.

It probably doesn't help as much, Alan Walker is half Norwegian/Norwegian. If I remember right, he lived in Norway since he was 3, with norwegian parents. He has made much beautiful music, and got his breakthrough in 2015 with the song “Faded”.
